  3537. I like that it comes with a small brush to clean the debris ( dry skin) from the roller area
  3538. I'm on my feet all day at work and developed lots of dry skin and calluses over the winter.
  3539. This cream plus the &#34;ProLinc Dry Heel Eliminator&#34; cream have completely reversed the process.
  3540. But, I can see that the sanding rollers are going to be needing frequent replacements - they are not going to last long.
  3541. The second time I turned it on, it barely moved and burned my hand when I opened the back to check on the batteries!
  3542. I must have had horse hooves because that first roller didn't last but just a few times.
  3543. like others it does a good job but a little under powered, if you press hard it bogs way down
  3544. If feet have tough calluses, this just isn't strong enough to do the job.
  3545. I can shave down the callus much more safely and can get them down as low as I need to without accidentally going too deep or cutting myself.
  3546. A small cleaning brush is included which is only mildly useful and likely to get lost as there's no way to store it in or on the device.
  3547. I spent $200 on the new Clarisonic Pedicure tool; I took it back two weeks after purchase.
  3548. Works very well on removing those rough dry spots from your feet.
  3549. easily removes the dried dead skin from your feet.
  3550. Less powerful than had expected.
  3551. It seems a little pricey to me, plus the little rollers aren't cheap.
  3552. Really does work to get rid of the dry, rough white scaly skin that never goes away with just lotions.
  3553. Products functions exactly as described, and seller extremely prompt with shipping, and careful in packaging.
  3554. I live in the Arizona desert, dry, dry, and dry, so rough and callused feet are a real problem.
  3555. The batteries run out very fast usually after one use.
  3556. />After all the time I spent with other things, within seconds, this callus was ground down to a comfortable level.
  3557. I started with the green refill (x-treme coarse) since my feet was in such horrid condition and now am going to buy the blue refill (extra coarse) to maintain my new found soft feet.
  3558. Powerful little thing!!
  3559. works good - my heels were really bad.
  3560. it cleared the skin off my bad spots.... really have enjoyed it.mm

  3. I bought this for my husband. This winter his heels really started to get thick, tough, dry, cracked skin. This tool has made a huge difference on his feet. They are softer and smoother with every use. He said you need to be careful not to use it too long each time, because he went a little too long once and his foot bled a little. He uses it every other day and that seems fine. The blue extra-coarse rollers seem to hold up well.

Within minutes of using the micro-pedi, my feet were much smoother. There is still some roughness in spots, but I was using an extra coarse roller. I just purchased the super coarse to finish the job. I suspect that if you continue to use it regularly, those rough spots will quickly be cleared up as well. I would also recommend following the callus removing with Vaseline or foot cream to moisturize the skin revealed.

  59. I bought this one for my daughter because I really like the one I have had for quite a while--months and months.<br /><br />I go barefoot a lot--especially in the summer, and my heels get very rough. I have tried metal scrapers and pumice stones, but they really don't do the job--the effort required is too much. (And I don't think they would ever work to my satisfaction.) This battery-operated roller requires little effort on the part of the operator and gets rid of LOTS of callus. You need to position your foot over something to catch the powdery skin as it falls. I'm tall and I stand in front of my bathroom sink, put my foot up on the counter and let my heel hang over the bowl. I'm always surprised at the amount that accumulates in the bowl--it's almost like face powder.<br /><br />CAUTION: If the roller slows down, you're using two much pressure. Lighten up a bit. OR maybe your batteries need to be changed. I just changed my batteries for the first time and it did make a difference.<br /><br />ADVICE: Use the roller often. It's easy and won't take long if you use it regularly--say once or twice a week. AND THEN use lotion on your feet when you finish.

I was very surprised that the instructions state that a roller should last only 1 or 2 sessions. That seems like a rip -off for something you may use several times a week. The price is less attractive when you factor in replacement rollers and that only one is included. Batteries aren't included either and I'm not sure yet how long those will last.   237. I bought this to remove dead skin off the palms of my hands due to a condition called dyshidrosis. I tried using other products, but they were either ineffective at removing the dead skin or they affected the healthy skin just as much as the dead skin which only made things worse.<br /><br />So I decided to give this product a try, and I couldn't be happier! It very quickly removes the dead skin without being so harsh as to remove a lot of the healthy skin around it. I think that's partly because it works on dry skin more than moist skin. I also love that I don't have to press very hard for it to work. That way any dead skin that's raised up gets worked on more, leaving the healthier skin below unharmed. What this means is when a blister opens up causing a spot on my hand with newly exposed skin in the center encircled by thick, dead skin, I can use this to remove the dead skin without harming the new skin in the middle. You just can't do that with any other product! Removing the dead skin means it won't catch on anything and I won't pick on it so the whole area is able to heal much faster and with less pain.<br /><br />Okay, but what about all these reports that the callus remover stalls and sputters if you apply too much pressure? I decided to try it on the calluses on my heels just to see how well it worked, and it was amazing. First and foremost—IT NEVER STALLED OR SPUTTERED WITH PRESSURE! Instead, it created a mountain of powder from my old calluses. The only thing I can think of that might be making a difference is that I did not use regular alkaline batteries. I used lithium batteries instead. I don't know if that's why mine never stalled, but it doesn't hurt to try.<br /><br />The only drawbacks I can see with this product is that it's possible to overuse it, causing damage to tender, healthy skin because it works so fast and so efficiently. I think it's important to do only a little at a time just to be sure you haven't gone too far. The other drawback is that it can be messy. It creates a mountain of powdered skin cells that go everywhere if you don't stop and clean it up as you go. A damp washcloth should help control the mess.<br /><br />Overall, I highly recommend this product for anyone who wants to remove dead skin. This is basically a skin sander which works very effectively. Just be careful to use it wisely because it is so fast and efficient, you can remove more skin than you realize in a short amount of time.that it can be messy. It creates a mountain of powdered skin cells that go everywhere if you don't stop and clean it up as you go. A damp washcloth should help control the mess.<br /><br />Overall, I highly recommend this product for anyone who wants to remove dead skin. This is basically a skin sander which works very effectively. Just be careful to use it wisely because it is so fast and efficient, you can remove more skin than you realize in a short amount of time.

  257. First let’s get the negative out of the way. There is no way I would pay the list price of $70 for this product, it’s pushing it at $20 in my opinion. That said, I really like the job it does. I have never, in my over 50 years, had a pedicure and it showed. My feet were covered on the sides and heel with hard, thick callouses as were my big toes. With the included sanding roller, the first use scrubbed away years of dead skin and made my son remark that it looked like I was building a small, white mountain on the floor. I have continued to use it over the past couple weeks and it has smoothed out my feet to the point that I have almost no pain on the previously hard areas of my feet. The speed of the roller is a little slow for me but I guess if it ran like a belt sander, one might start to make smoke signals or something. It will bog down if you push too hard and I think that ends up being a good thing; you keepsanding with gentle, firm pressure for best results. I’m very happy with the product.

It is also very easy to use. Be sure to get refills of the Emjoy Micro-Pedi Refill Rollers on an as-needed basis. The rollers come in different colors based on their level of coarseness. As for this little gem, it is small, requires 2 AA batteries and is very easy to use. You will see results immediately. Not only will it gently buff off dead skin, it will work like a miniature construction crew on calluses and corns. Just follow instructions and don't buff one area for more than 2-3 seconds. You will be delighted with the results! Be sure to wash your feet afterwards; lotion them and you will see an immediate difference!<br /><br />Although I liked this micropedi, the [[ASIN:B00O0GBRL6 Silk'n Electronic Pedicure File and Callus Remover]] does a much better job.   288. Note: Please see my comment below this original review, written after 3 uses. I'm revising my opinion and have written the Sellers to try and return. (I originally gave it a 4-star review and realized I was overly enthusiastic.) Easy to use and it DOES work! But, I wish the unit's top plastic wrap-around part, that surrounds the dark blue sander portion, exposed MORE of the spinning sander. The design forces you to be able to only rub the unit across your heels along the FRONT of the unit - along its front side - instead of a more-natural position of wanting to sand with it across the TOP of the unit. Much like the analogy of a men's shaver, where he uses it across the top of the razor to shave his face, with this unit, you have to sand your feet across the front face of the unit, making it a little awkward to use. There MUST be some reason for this design, but I can't imagine why. Otherwise, it DOES do what it's supposed to. But, I can see that the sanding rollers are going to be needing frequent replacements - they are not going to last long. Be sure to order the extra replacements with your order of this unit - purchased on a different listing on Amazon (haven't used those yet). Once your initial sanding has been done, a little &#34;touch up&#34; every 2-3 weeks keeps your feet nice and smooth.

  364. This thing is so over-hyped. The initial roll lost its abrasiveness after one session. Foolishly, I went and bought the nineteen dollar replacement rolls. They work, but it says right on the package that each roll only lasts for a few &#34;sessions.&#34; That's a very expensive, and very time-consuming, foot treatment.<br /><br />Here's the thing-- this is more of a buffer than any kind of smoother or callus remover. It takes a very, very long time to remove even a little dried skin. I could easily spend 30 minutes trying to remove dry skin from just one foot with how slowly this &#34;powerful&#34; tool works, and by then the roll would be useless. I got frustrated at one point and brought out my old pumice stone, and wow did I feel foolish-- the cheap pumice stone did a much better job in a fraction of the time.<br /><br />I do think it's helpful for getting into smaller areas-- dry skin around nails, and dry skin under toes-- but for everything else a simple pumice stone works about a thousand times better than the emjoi, and it won't cost you ten dollars for each replacement roll.<br /><br />Remember when there was a trend for those silly, weak little gadgets that removed sweater lint? That's what this emjoi reminds me of. It's weak, it's pricey, and when you're sitting around for 15 minutes trying to soften up your heels (when a pumice stone could do the job in about 30 seconds), you start to feel pretty foolish for believing the hype.

Small , compact and handy tool that can save you lots of time and the motor is powerful enough for extended usage(more than 20 minutes) The easiest way to clean the roller is by using canned air duster while the unit is on/when roller is spinning/.Just move the air nozzle left and right 2-3 times from a close distance and you're done with the cleaning process.   442. The roller on the Emjoi foot sander is so weakly-powered that anything more than the slightest pressure causes the speed to drop dramatically and renders the entire device essentially useless. Other reviews recommended using &#34;light pressure&#34; while you operate it; however, if you have anything more than the barest of calluses, it will take AGES for you to make any noticeable progress. I originally bought one to replace a foot file I'd been using, but after several attempts at using the Emjoi, I went back to using the foot file. Essentially, it's a toss-up between a little elbow grease to remove calluses or spending roughly an hour in each spot to get anything done. Honestly, I can't see why anyone would think this product is good. You're better off with something, literally anything, else. The only upside I could see was the price; I only wasted $25 on the thing.

  677. I bought this because I'm kind of obsessed with all my body parts looking good especially my feet. I'm not really vain I just can't stand people that don't take care of themselves. It will bog down if you really push on it but honestly this Emjoi really does sand down your feet to a baby soft feel. It really takes off the dead skin and calluses. I think the corded one and rechargeable one might have more power but this is really a very good buy and you can get different types of rollers for it. I just ordered the super coarse green rollers but the one this comes with the extra coarse are great but the green ones are probably amazing. You can get the generic rollers , a pack of 4 pretty cheap and they look just as good. I bought them but haven't opened the package yet. Haven't needed to. I don't think you'll be disappointed in this as it really does the job and feels pretty good doing it. 2 AA batteries that so far have not worn out after about 6 uses. Very happy with this.<br />EDIT: The green rollers came and I used it last night. They work even better then the standard blue one what came with the device. They are more abrasive and sand off even more dead skin. My feet are smooth as can be and my girlfriend is amazed with how well this thing works. I also noticed that if you use the lower quality batteries this thing bogs down somewhat if you press even a little hard. HOWEVER, if you buy good batteries - I bought the generic CVS alkalines that were on sale. They are basically the Duracell I think with the CVS name. They worked much better in that you can push down now pretty hard on the machine and it won't stop rolling nearly as easily as it did with less quality batteries. So, to sum up. The better batteries and the green rollers are the way to go. I don't really have super rough feet but the amount of skin this takes off is pretty amazing. Now my feet are amazingly smooth and I use this every day anyway to keep up on them. Ok, so I'm a little obsessive. Not sure how anyone can give this a low rating as it works great unless you have feet that look like a million year old stone and you don't press so hard that your knuckles turn white which you wouldn't have to anyway. This is a great little device. You can't go wrong buying it and it't inexpensive too.
  678. I was on the fence with this one because of some that gave it 1 or 2 stars but this does exactly what it advertises to do. I have little time for a pedi with two toddlers. This removes more than the technician can. You won't be diappointed. I love this tool!!!!
  679. This device really works...well!!!! Desert climate, constant air conditioned house, hard tile floor = horrible, cracked, bleeding feet! This product is easy to use and works like a charm.   1032. Does make the skin on your feet smoother. Doesn't remove skin as quickly as the egg with metal scraper. However, it would also be really, really hard (maybe impossible) to hurt yourself by accidentally removing too much skin, as can happen with the egg if you're not careful. The egg also doesn't really leave your feet smooth, it just kind of roughly takes off the dead skin. I ordered the extra extra course rollers--the best ones are the knock offs, they are coarser than the brand name. I've only used it a few times, and I had to change the batteries already. It was still working, but I felt it was kind of getting less effective. When I changed the batteries, it definitely began doing a better job. It takes a really long time to really do a thorough job on your feet. I spent a good 30-40 minutes using it today. My feet are less rough--I'd even say they're smooth, but they're not perfect--they still have some tough skin. I still like this thing, because I'm not aware of anything else out there that's better at this point. If someone is, please tell me!!! This thing works OK on my feet, but to put a dent in my husband's elephant-skin feet, I think would take days, maybe longer. He did give it a whirl, but it wasn't really strong enough to get through his thick callouses. My feet aren't as bad as his because I use the egg periodically.<br /><br />I allowed the skin to fall onto a flat surface so I could see how much this machine was getting off my feet. After 40 minutes, there was a pile of skin flakes. However, not as much as the pile that builds up inside the egg when I've used it. And that I can do in 5 minutes or less. Plus, I felt like I could have continued to use it, it's just that I don't have all day to give myself a pedicure, so I kind of stopped because I hadn't allocated that much of my day to working on my feet.<br /><br />To the manufacturers...this thing needs to be more powerful, and the rollers need to be rougher. I know you probablydon't make it more powerful, because you're afraid brain-cell-challenged people will hurt themselves, so you made it perfectly safe. Those of us with brain cells, would prefer the option of a more powerful/effective machine, that would allow us to complete the job more effectively and in less time. We're very busy people. We're busy using our brain cells, and out earning a living so that we can afford to buy your foot pedicure products. We don't have 40 minutes a day to spend removing the dead skin from our feet. How about you make one that will effectively do this in 5 minutes? We'll sign a waiver, and use it at our own risk. You don't see the egg-manufacturers getting sued, do you?<br /><br />In sum...not the be-all, end-all, but in my opinion, worth having. I'm glad I bought it, and I will continue to use it. Maybe the best thing to do is use the egg first, then smooth your feet out with this after you finish? Wish someone would make one product strong enough to really get your feet smooth and soft. But, at the end of the day, if you have a little extra time. you might be pleased with how this thing takes the rough edges off the heals of your feet.

  1116. I had feet that were in really rough shape -- I had spent some time working overseas on a medical mission and hadn't had a pedicure in maybe 10+ months. I really like this device. It is very easy to use, doesn't hurt, and is effective. My only complaint is that I notice my feet initially feel very smooth, but feel rough again in unusual patterns by the next morning. This goes away with another Emjoi &#34;treatment&#34;.   1127. I ordered this product from a tv demonstration so I didn't have very high expectations. But boy, was I surprised! It worked just like demonstrated, very quickly turned my dry, cracked hiking feet into pink and smooth. It won't get rid of thick calluses with just one use, but it does make your whole sole smooth and even and ready for your dressiest sandals. Be sure to follow the directions, including wiping the dust off your feet with a damp towel and using a moisturizating cream afterwards. Who cares what color the roller is, as long as it works! The directions specify that if you press hard, the device will stop. The trick is to press very lightly, as if you were filing your nails. Also, make sure your batteries are fresh. My one complaint is that the packaging didn't give any info on where to order refill rollers, but that's what Google is for, I guess. Good to know I can get them here! This would make a great gift for a female relative, or anyone who likes regular pedicures, especially if they can't afford to go as often as they'd like.

I agree 100% with other reviewers that say it's not very powerful (neither was Amope, to be honest), but for safety purposes, I'm sure it needs to work slowly so people don't burn holes in their feet and sue them.<br /><br />The other way Amope exceeds over Emjoi is the head of the filer. Emjoi only gives a small little area of open file and it's very difficult to keep the area you're working on in that tiny window. Amope's head is wide open, so you can move that thing in any direction and have sweet, sweet access to the file.

  1259. This is an awesome product as it does the job well. My first as I've seen the bigger brother (one) on a Canadian shopping channel, so decided to get this for a test drive, here in the States. It WORKS and works well ONLY on dry feet/heels. I made the mistake of using it after I showed and that's a no no. Your heels HAS to be dry, at a point where they look whitish/ashy due to build-up of dead heel skins. It DOES leave my heels a bit tender in spots that I went over a few times; that was my own fault. I use it, shower and then apply Vaseline all over my feet and heels and wear an old pair of sport socks before I hit the sheets. In the morning, my feet and heels are near perfect. Repeat every night, but only use the Nano Pedi once a week. No need to buy &#34;special&#34; foot cream, Vaseline and a pair of soft socks work the best. My ONLY problem with this Nano Pedi is, it is a bit on the small side for a guy's feet; the roller is too small. Another thing, wash the roller in warm water and use a nail brush to remove the dead skin on it.

I bought this for the price of a pedicure in my area and therefore consider this little device already paid for for that reason!

I have only used the Emjoi Micro-Pedi Nano once so far, but I got such good results with minimum elbow grease that I feel compelled to write a review. This is like a mini power sander and you use it much as you would a sander on the callused areas of your feet. Be prepared for soft feet after the first use. This pedi tool is amazing! I'm also going to use it to &#34;file down&#34; the corns I have on my little toes. Rechargeable model would most likely work well, but not sure if I want to have yet another item to constantly maintain a charge. The corded version was quite a bit more $$. I went for budget and glad I did. Will use rechargeable batteries.<br /><br />Used my small bathroom trash to catch the shavings. That worked well to contain quite a bit of shavings that were removed. No &#34;dust up&#34; occurred...all filed skin dropped into the waste basket.<br /><br />Will stick with the Extra and Super Course roller files since my feet are mildly callused.

I am glad that I did because all of the skin that is removed from your feet is turned into a fine dust and it goes all over the place. I didn't give this a 5 star rating because I have to replace the batteries frequently. I have resorted to using rechargeable batteries to save money and that seems to have helped alot. I use this every other day, and I recharge the batteries after my 2nd use. When I use this product, I do the bottom of my entire foot and then around the heals and I concentrate on the balls of my feet for both feet. This device is defintely for maintenance and not a one time cure-all but it is so much easier than using stones, sand paper, or other items which require alot of effort and pressure to do half the job this little thing can do.<br /><br />Make sure to do the following and you should have no problems with your device. Enjoy!<br /><br /> * Keep your batteries fresh (change out about every other use depending on how much you use it each time - I suggest rechargeable)<br /> * Clean the roller after each use (I take mine out and run it under water and then dry it off)<br /> * Clean the device after each use (I take a paper towel and wipe off the device before I place the roller back in it)<br /> * Be sure to use a light pressure when using the device or it will not work.

  1393. I'm really glad I bought this Emjoi Micro-Pedi. First, for the obvious reason, to remove calluses and make my feet pretty again. Second, my feet get really dry in the winter and start itching, and even slathering on moisturizers is only a temporary help. I'm finding when I keep the dry skin sanded off and as much dead skin removed as possible the itching has lessened dramatically. (BTW, my feet don't have a fungus). I've used pumice, those long black emery file things, those \\"cheese grater\\" eggs, and got tired of all the stretching and bending and contorting you have to go through to reach all the areas you need to. Sometimes, I felt like I'd just done an exercise routine, worn out. The ease of use of these battery operated callus removers quickly sold me. I bought the Emjoi instead of the Amope for a couple of reasons. First, the reviews on the Emjoi convinced me the unit is a good one, and the price was better. Second, I like how the Emjoi's sanding roller isn't totally exposed, just on one side. That means the dry skin isn't flying all over the place and you won't find fine white skin dust on your ceiling fan if you don't do it in a bathtub; can be easily directed towards a paper towel for easy gather-up and disposal. I have zero problems with it being battery operated. So far, I've used it maybe 5 times and the sanding roller still has a lot of life left in it. It turns on and off easily; the roller comes out very easily for cleaning; the unit is small and can easily be held in one hand; it is easy to reach pretty much all areas of your feet and toes. If you bear down the motor will slow down, so don't bear down. Just go back and forth a few times and have faith the roller is doing its job. And it's quite satisfying when you're done to see lovely smooth sandal-worthy feet. Hope all this helps. I do recommend the Emjoi, can't think of any negatives, really.
